text: Thought this link to a new book would be of interest of the audience of this slack group...based on the 2010 Flash Crash and Navinder Sarao, who amassed $70m from his bedroom at his mum and dads house in London. He used strategies not too unlike what some of use on Betfair using software he developed himself. due for release mid may <https://www.amazon.co.uk/Flash-Crash-Trading-Manhunt-Mysterious-ebook/dp/B07XZ7CY7N/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=flash+crash&qid=1586686107&s=books&sr=1-1>

attachments.title: The Psychology of Money: Timeless lessons on wealth, greed, and happiness
attachments.text: Doing well with money isn’t necessarily about what you know. It’s about how you behave. And behavior is hard to teach, even to really smart people.Money―investing, personal finance, and business decisions―is typically taught as a math-based field, where data and formulas tell us exactly what to d...

text: <@UBS7QANF3> Is it frowned upon by betfair to have a low matched (settled ) bet ratio. EG, I submitted around 1000 bets on the first US meeting last night but only 19 settled bets...I would think not, but Ill be stepping it up significantly soon and just wondered if there is a point at which it could be considered an issue? Thanks

elements.text: Is it frowned upon by betfair to have a low matched (settled ) bet ratio. EG, I submitted around 1000 bets on the first US meeting last night but only 19 settled bets...I would think not, but Ill be stepping it up significantly soon and just wondered if there is a point at which it could be considered an issue? Thanks

text: I don't think they're looking at that ratio per se, just the number of bets that you submit. Neil said at the meetup that they are looking to crack down on the worst offenders
